pages.name: CLSI Breakpoints and MIC Interpretation
content: The Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) publishes evidence-based guidelines for antimicrobial susceptibility testing (AST) that are recognized by the FDA and used worldwide. On January 16, 2025, the FDA recognized CLSI M100 35th Edition (2025), M45 3rd Edition (2025), M27/M44 3rd Edition (2025), M38/M51 3rd Edition (2025), and M24S 2nd Edition (2025), representing a major advancement in standardizing AST interpretation and combating antimicrobial resistance.

CLSI M100 35th Edition (2025) - Performance Standards for Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing: This document provides breakpoints for aerobic and anaerobic bacteria. Breakpoint categories include: Susceptible (S) - the antimicrobial is likely to inhibit growth of the pathogen if the antimicrobial reaches the concentrations at the infection site; Intermediate (I) - the antimicrobial may be effective at higher doses or at sites where the drug is concentrated (e.g., urine); Resistant (R) - the antimicrobial is not likely to inhibit growth even with maximal dosing; Susceptible-Dose Dependent (SDD) - susceptibility depends on the dosing regimen (higher doses may be required).

MIC (Minimum Inhibitory Concentration) is the lowest concentration of an antimicrobial that inhibits visible growth of a microorganism after overnight incubation. MIC values guide dosing decisions and predict clinical outcomes. For example, vancomycin MIC 1.5 g/mL for MRSA bacteremia is associated with treatment failure, even though the breakpoint for susceptibility is 2 g/mL. Understanding MIC values beyond categorical interpretation (S/I/R) is critical for antimicrobial stewardship.

Pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic (PK/PD) breakpoints are based on the relationship between drug exposure and microbiological effect. Time-dependent antibiotics (e.g., beta-lactams) require time above MIC (T>MIC) for efficacy; concentration-dependent antibiotics (e.g., aminoglycosides, fluoroquinolones) require peak concentration/MIC (Cmax/MIC) or area under the curve/MIC (AUC/MIC) ratios. PK/PD principles guide dosing optimization and breakpoint determination.

Recent breakpoint updates in CLSI M100 35th Edition (2025): Ceftazidime-avibactam for CRE (Carbapenem-Resistant Enterobacterales) - S 8 g/mL, R 16 g/mL; Cefiderocol (siderophore cephalosporin) - requires iron-depleted media for accurate testing, S 4 g/mL for Enterobacterales and P. aeruginosa; Meropenem-vaborbactam for Enterobacterales - S 4 g/mL, R 16 g/mL; Imipenem-relebactam for Enterobacterales and P. aeruginosa - S 2 g/mL, R 8 g/mL. These new agents provide critical treatment options for multidrug-resistant Gram-negative infections.

CLSI M45 3rd Edition (2025) - Methods for Antimicrobial Dilution and Disk Susceptibility Testing of Infrequently Isolated or Fastidious Bacteria: This document covers organisms that require special media or incubation conditions, including H. influenzae, M. catarrhalis, N. gonorrhoeae, N. meningitidis, S. pneumoniae, Streptococcus groups A/B/C/G, HACEK organisms (Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella), and nutritionally variant streptococci (Abiotrophia, Granulicatella). Special requirements include chocolate agar, extended incubation (5-7 days for HACEK), CO atmosphere, and pyridoxal supplementation for nutritionally variant streptococci.

CLSI M27/M44 3rd Edition (2025) - Reference Method for Broth Dilution Antifungal Susceptibility Testing of Yeasts: This document provides breakpoints for Candida species and other yeasts. Echinocandins (caspofungin, micafungin, anidulafungin) are first-line therapy for candidemia; azoles (fluconazole, voriconazole) are used for less severe infections or step-down therapy. C. glabrata is intrinsically susceptible-dose dependent (SDD) to fluconazole; C. krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole. Broth microdilution is the reference method; disk diffusion is NOT validated for antifungal testing.

CLSI M38/M51 3rd Edition (2025) - Reference Method for Broth Dilution Antifungal Susceptibility Testing of Filamentous Fungi: This document covers molds such as Aspergillus species. Voriconazole and isavuconazole are first-line agents for invasive aspergillosis; amphotericin B is an alternative. Antifungal susceptibility testing for molds is technically challenging and should be performed by reference laboratories.

Clinical implications of breakpoint changes for stewardship: Updated breakpoints reflect new PK/PD data, clinical outcomes, and resistance mechanisms. Stewardship programs must stay current with CLSI updates to ensure appropriate empiric therapy selection, antibiogram interpretation, and prescriber education. For example, recognizing ceftazidime-avibactam susceptibility in CRE allows targeted therapy instead of colistin or tigecycline, which have more toxicity and lower efficacy.

Quality control and proficiency testing: Laboratories must perform daily quality control (QC) using ATCC reference strains to ensure accurate AST results. QC failures require investigation and corrective action before reporting patient results. Proficiency testing (e.g., College of American Pathologists surveys) ensures ongoing competency and identifies systematic errors. Stewardship teams should collaborate with microbiology laboratories to review QC data and address discrepancies.

pages.name: MIC Testing and Clinical Scenarios
content: MIC testing methods: Broth microdilution is the gold standard reference method, providing quantitative MIC values in g/mL. E-test (gradient diffusion) provides MIC values and is useful for fastidious organisms or when automated systems are unavailable. Automated systems (e.g., Vitek 2, MicroScan, Phoenix) provide rapid results (4-18 hours) but may have limitations for certain organism-drug combinations. Disk diffusion (Kirby-Bauer) provides categorical results (S/I/R) based on zone diameters but does not provide MIC values.

Vancomycin MIC and MRSA bacteremia: Vancomycin has been the cornerstone of MRSA bacteremia treatment for decades, but MIC creep (gradual increase in MIC values over time) is associated with treatment failure. MRSA isolates with vancomycin MIC 1.5 g/mL (even though susceptible by CLSI breakpoint of 2 g/mL) have higher rates of treatment failure, persistent bacteremia, and mortality. IDSA guidelines (2011, updated 2021) recommend E-test for all positive MRSA blood cultures to guide therapy decisions.

Heteroresistant VISA (hVISA) detection: hVISA refers to MRSA isolates with subpopulations that have reduced vancomycin susceptibility (MIC 4-8 g/mL). hVISA is not detected by routine AST but is associated with vancomycin treatment failure. Detection methods include population analysis profiling (PAP-AUC, gold standard but labor-intensive) and screening methods (e.g., vancomycin screen agar with 6 g/mL). Clinical suspicion for hVISA: Persistent MRSA bacteremia despite adequate vancomycin dosing (AUC/MIC 400), MIC 1.5 g/mL, or prior vancomycin exposure.

Alternative agents for MRSA bacteremia when vancomycin MIC 1.5 g/mL or hVISA suspected: Daptomycin 8-10 mg/kg/day (higher doses for bacteremia/endocarditis); Linezolid 600 mg IV/PO q12h (bacteriostatic, avoid for high-burden infections); Ceftaroline 600 mg IV q8h (bactericidal, excellent for MRSA bacteremia and endocarditis); Combination therapy (vancomycin + beta-lactam) may have synergy. Clinical scenario: 65-year-old man with MRSA bacteremia, vancomycin MIC = 2 g/mL by E-test, persistent bacteremia on day 5 despite vancomycin AUC = 450  Switch to daptomycin 10 mg/kg/day or ceftaroline 600 mg q8h.

Streptococcus pneumoniae site-specific breakpoints (CRITICAL): Penicillin and cephalosporin breakpoints for S. pneumoniae differ based on infection site due to differences in drug penetration and required bacterial killing. Meningitis breakpoints are much stricter than non-meningitis breakpoints. Penicillin: Meningitis S 0.06 g/mL (R 0.12 g/mL); Non-meningitis oral S 2 g/mL, IV S 8 g/mL. Ceftriaxone/cefotaxime: Meningitis S 0.5 g/mL (R 1 g/mL); Non-meningitis S 1 g/mL (R 4 g/mL).

Clinical scenario - S. pneumoniae meningitis: 45-year-old woman with bacterial meningitis, CSF culture grows S. pneumoniae with penicillin MIC = 0.12 g/mL. Interpretation: Resistant for meningitis (breakpoint S 0.06 g/mL) but susceptible for non-meningitis infections (oral breakpoint S 2 g/mL). Treatment: Vancomycin 15-20 mg/kg q8-12h + ceftriaxone 2 g q12h (empiric for meningitis). If ceftriaxone MIC 0.5 g/mL, continue ceftriaxone alone. Avoid penicillin monotherapy for meningitis even if 'susceptible' by non-meningitis breakpoints.

Enterococcus species and vancomycin resistance: Vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) are a major healthcare-associated pathogen. VRE screening detects vanA and vanB genes (high-level resistance, MIC >256 g/mL). Daptomycin is first-line therapy for VRE bacteremia; however, daptomycin MIC testing requires calcium-adjusted media (50 mg/L Ca) per CLSI guidelines. Linezolid 600 mg q12h is an alternative, but resistance is emerging (23S rRNA mutations). Clinical scenario: 70-year-old man with E. faecium bacteremia, vancomycin-resistant (vanA gene), daptomycin MIC = 4 g/mL (susceptible 4 g/mL)  Start daptomycin 8-10 mg/kg/day or consider linezolid if daptomycin MIC is elevated.

Candida species and antifungal susceptibility (CRITICAL): Candidemia is a life-threatening infection with 40% mortality. Echinocandins (caspofungin, micafungin, anidulafungin) are first-line therapy per IDSA guidelines (2016, updated 2024). Antifungal susceptibility testing uses broth microdilution (CLSI M27/M44 3rd Ed. 2025); disk diffusion is NOT validated. C. albicans: Fluconazole S 2 g/mL, R 8 g/mL. C. glabrata: Intrinsically SDD to fluconazole (S 32 g/mL with high-dose therapy); echinocandins preferred. C. krusei: Intrinsically resistant to fluconazole. C. auris: Often resistant to fluconazole (90%) and amphotericin B (30-40%); echinocandin resistance emerging (5-10%).

Clinical scenario - C. glabrata candidemia: 60-year-old woman with candidemia, blood culture grows C. glabrata, fluconazole MIC = 16 g/mL (SDD). Interpretation: Susceptible-dose dependent; high-dose fluconazole (800 mg daily) may be effective, but echinocandins are preferred due to superior efficacy and lower resistance rates. Treatment: Micafungin 100 mg IV daily or anidulafungin 200 mg loading dose, then 100 mg daily. Stewardship implication: Antifungal stewardship programs should review all candidemia cases for appropriate agent selection, dosing, and duration (14 days after first negative blood culture and resolution of symptoms).

Neisseria gonorrhoeae and cephalosporin resistance (HIGH PRIORITY): N. gonorrhoeae is a CDC urgent threat due to rising cephalosporin resistance. Ceftriaxone MIC creep: MIC 0.125 g/mL is concerning (CDC surveillance threshold); treatment failures reported with MIC 0.5 g/mL. Current CDC treatment recommendation (2020): Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM single dose (1 g if weight >150 kg). Azithromycin is no longer recommended for dual therapy due to high-level resistance (MIC 256 g/mL). Clinical scenario: 25-year-old man with urethral discharge, culture grows N. gonorrhoeae with ceftriaxone MIC = 0.25 g/mL. Interpretation: Susceptible (breakpoint S 0.25 g/mL) but concerning due to MIC creep. Action: Treat with ceftriaxone 500 mg IM, report elevated MIC to public health, perform test-of-cure culture in 1 week.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa and difficult-to-treat resistance (DTR-PA): DTR-PA is defined as P. aeruginosa resistant to all beta-lactams (piperacillin-tazobactam, ceftazidime, cefepime, meropenem, imipenem) AND fluoroquinolones. DTR-PA is associated with high mortality (30-40%) and limited treatment options. Treatment options: Ceftolozane-tazobactam 3 g q8h (extended infusion), ceftazidime-avibactam 2.5 g q8h, imipenem-relebactam 1.25 g q6h, colistin (last resort due to nephrotoxicity). Clinical scenario: 55-year-old man with ventilator-associated pneumonia, sputum culture grows P. aeruginosa with meropenem MIC = 4 g/mL (intermediate). Action: Consider higher-dose meropenem (2 g q8h extended infusion over 3 hours) or switch to ceftolozane-tazobactam. Stewardship implication: Early identification of DTR-PA triggers infectious diseases consultation and consideration of newer agents.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis drug susceptibility testing: First-line drugs for TB include rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. Molecular methods provide rapid resistance detection: GeneXpert MTB/RIF detects rifampin resistance (rpoB gene mutations) in 2 hours with 95% sensitivity and 98% specificity; line probe assays (e.g., GenoType MTBDRplus) detect resistance to rifampin and isoniazid. Phenotypic DST is required for second-line drugs (fluoroquinolones, aminoglycosides, bedaquiline) and confirmation of molecular results. Stewardship implication: Rapid rifampin resistance detection guides empiric therapy (MDR-TB regimen with fluoroquinolone + bedaquiline + linezolid vs. standard 4-drug regimen for drug-susceptible TB).

pages.name: Rapid Diagnostics and Stewardship Integration
content: MALDI-TOF MS (Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry) provides rapid organism identification in minutes compared to days for conventional methods. MALDI-TOF analyzes protein profiles to identify bacteria and fungi with >95% accuracy for common pathogens. Impact on time to appropriate therapy: MALDI-TOF reduces time to organism identification by 24-48 hours, allowing earlier de-escalation from empiric broad-spectrum therapy or escalation to targeted therapy. Stewardship workflow integration: Real-time alerts for positive blood cultures (text/pager alerts to stewardship team) enable pharmacist-driven interventions within hours of organism identification.

C. auris identification via MALDI-TOF (CRITICAL): C. auris is a CDC urgent threat due to multidrug resistance, environmental persistence, and outbreak potential. Conventional methods (API, Vitek 2) misidentify C. auris as C. haemulonii or C. duobushaemulonii. MALDI-TOF or molecular methods (PCR, sequencing) are required for accurate identification. Clinical implication: Early C. auris identification triggers infection control measures (contact precautions, dedicated equipment, environmental disinfection with sporicidal agents) and appropriate antifungal selection (echinocandin first-line; avoid fluconazole due to 90% resistance rate).

Molecular rapid diagnostic panels: Blood culture panels (e.g., BioFire FilmArray BCID, Verigene, T2Candida) provide organism identification and resistance gene detection in 1-3 hours directly from positive blood cultures. Organisms detected: Gram-positive (S. aureus, Enterococcus, Streptococcus), Gram-negative (E. coli, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas, Acinetobacter), Candida species. Resistance genes detected: mecA (MRSA), vanA/vanB (VRE), KPC, NDM, OXA-48, VIM, IMP (carbapenemases). Respiratory panels detect viral and bacterial pathogens (influenza, RSV, SARS-CoV-2, S. pneumoniae, M. pneumoniae), reducing unnecessary antibiotics for viral infections. Gastrointestinal panels detect bacterial, viral, and parasitic pathogens (Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, C. difficile, norovirus, Giardia).

Clostridioides difficile testing algorithms (CRITICAL): C. difficile is the most common healthcare-associated infection in the United States, causing 500,000 infections and 29,000 deaths annually. However, 10-30% of hospitalized patients are colonized with C. difficile (carry the organism without symptoms). PCR-only testing (1-step NAAT) has high sensitivity but detects both colonization and infection, leading to over-diagnosis and overtreatment. IDSA/SHEA guidelines (2021) recommend 2-step or 3-step algorithms to improve specificity.

C. difficile testing algorithms: 1-step PCR (NAAT only) - High sensitivity (>95%) but detects colonization  Over-diagnosis, unnecessary treatment, isolation, and healthcare costs. 2-step algorithm (RECOMMENDED) - Step 1: GDH (glutamate dehydrogenase) antigen screen (high sensitivity, low specificity). Step 2: If GDH positive  Toxin EIA (enzyme immunoassay) for confirmation (high specificity). Result interpretation: GDH+/Toxin+ = Active CDI (treat); GDH+/Toxin- = Likely colonization (do not treat, consider alternative diagnosis); GDH-/Toxin- = Negative. 3-step algorithm (most specific) - Step 1: GDH screen. Step 2: If GDH positive  PCR. Step 3: If PCR positive  Toxin EIA for confirmation. This algorithm reduces false positives compared to PCR-only testing.

Stewardship implications for C. difficile testing: PCR-only testing leads to unnecessary treatment (metronidazole or vancomycin for colonization), prolonged isolation (contact precautions), and healthcare costs ($10,000-$30,000 per case). Repeat testing within 7 days is NOT recommended (IDSA/SHEA 2021) because PCR remains positive for weeks after treatment, even with clinical resolution. 'Test of cure' is NOT indicated; clinical improvement is the endpoint. Clinical scenario: 65-year-old woman with diarrhea (5 loose stools/day), positive C. difficile PCR, negative toxin EIA. Interpretation: Likely colonization, not active CDI. Action: Consider alternative diagnosis (laxatives, tube feeds, other infections), do not treat with metronidazole or vancomycin unless high clinical suspicion.

Stewardship action for C. difficile: Implement 2-step or 3-step testing algorithm (not PCR-only), restrict repeat testing within 7 days, educate prescribers on colonization vs. infection, review all positive results with clinical correlation. Expected outcomes: 30-50% reduction in CDI diagnosis rates, reduced unnecessary antibiotic use, cost savings, improved antibiotic stewardship metrics.

Syndromic panels and stewardship considerations: Positive predictive value (PPV) varies by prevalence; low PPV in low-prevalence settings leads to false positives. Colonization vs. infection: Respiratory panels may detect colonizers (S. aureus, S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae) that are not causing the current illness; clinical correlation is required. Risk of overtreatment: Broad panels may lead to unnecessary antibiotics for non-pathogenic organisms or viral infections. Stewardship review: Pharmacist or infectious diseases physician review of all positive results to guide appropriate therapy, de-escalation, or discontinuation.

Rapid AST technologies: Accelerate Pheno system provides organism identification and AST in 7 hours (vs. 48-72 hours for conventional methods) directly from positive blood cultures. Phenotypic AST provides MIC values for multiple antibiotics, allowing precise therapy selection. Genotypic resistance detection (e.g., GeneXpert for mecA, vanA/B, KPC) detects resistance genes but may miss novel mechanisms or heteroresistance. Combination of genotypic and phenotypic methods provides optimal stewardship guidance.

Stewardship integration strategies: Real-time alerts for positive blood cultures (text/pager alerts to stewardship team within 1 hour of MALDI-TOF or molecular panel result). Pharmacist-driven interventions: Review rapid diagnostic results and recommend de-escalation (e.g., MRSA-negative  discontinue vancomycin) or escalation (e.g., KPC-positive  start ceftazidime-avibactam). De-escalation protocols: Triggered by rapid AST results (e.g., ESBL-negative E. coli  de-escalate from meropenem to ceftriaxone). Metrics: Time to appropriate therapy (target <6 hours), time to de-escalation (target <24 hours), antibiotic days saved (target 20-30% reduction in broad-spectrum use).

pages.name: Resistance Mechanisms and AST Pitfalls
content: ESBL (Extended-Spectrum Beta-Lactamase) detection: ESBLs are enzymes that hydrolyze extended-spectrum cephalosporins (ceftriaxone, ceftazidime, cefotaxime) and aztreonam but are inhibited by clavulanate. CLSI M100 35th Edition (2025) provides phenotypic confirmation tests: Ceftazidime or cefotaxime with/without clavulanate; 5 mm increase in zone diameter with clavulanate indicates ESBL production. Resistance patterns: Resistance to ceftriaxone, ceftazidime, cefotaxime; usually susceptible to carbapenems and beta-lactam/beta-lactamase inhibitors (piperacillin-tazobactam). Clinical example: ESBL-producing E. coli with ceftriaxone 'susceptible' by automated system  Still avoid cephalosporins (use carbapenem or piperacillin-tazobactam) due to risk of treatment failure.

AmpC beta-lactamase detection: AmpC enzymes hydrolyze cephalosporins and are NOT inhibited by clavulanate. Inducible AmpC: Chromosomally encoded in Enterobacter, Citrobacter, Serratia, Morganella (ESCPM group); low-level expression at baseline but induced by cephalosporin exposure, leading to treatment failure. Constitutive AmpC: High-level expression due to mutations; resistant to all cephalosporins. Cefepime paradox: Cefepime may appear susceptible but can fail clinically with high inoculum or induction. Preferred therapy: Carbapenem (meropenem, imipenem) or high-dose cefepime (2 g q8h). Stewardship implication: Avoid ceftriaxone/ceftazidime for AmpC-producing organisms (risk of induction and treatment failure).

Carbapenemase detection: Carbapenemases hydrolyze carbapenems and most beta-lactams. Major types: KPC (Klebsiella pneumoniae carbapenemase, class A), NDM (New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase, class B), OXA-48 (class D), VIM/IMP (class B metallo-beta-lactamases). Phenotypic methods: Modified Carbapenem Inactivation Method (mCIM) detects all carbapenemases; EDTA-CIM detects metallo-beta-lactamases (NDM, VIM, IMP). Molecular methods: PCR for blaKPC, blaNDM, blaOXA-48, blaVIM, blaIMP. Stewardship implications: Infection control alerts (contact precautions, cohorting), public health reporting (CDC requires reporting of CRE), treatment with ceftazidime-avibactam (for KPC, OXA-48) or cefiderocol (for metallo-beta-lactamases). Clinical example: CRE with meropenem MIC = 2 g/mL (susceptible) but KPC-positive  Consider ceftazidime-avibactam or combination therapy (meropenem + colistin or tigecycline).

Heteroresistance: Heteroresistance refers to bacterial populations with subpopulations that have reduced susceptibility to an antimicrobial. Vancomycin heteroresistance (hVISA) in MRSA: Subpopulations with MIC 4-8 g/mL; associated with vancomycin treatment failure, persistent bacteremia, and poor outcomes. Detection requires population analysis profiling (PAP-AUC, labor-intensive). Clinical significance: hVISA is not detected by routine AST; suspect in patients with persistent MRSA bacteremia despite adequate vancomycin dosing. Colistin heteroresistance in CRE: Subpopulations resistant to colistin; associated with treatment failure. Detection requires population analysis. Clinical example: MRSA with vancomycin MIC = 1.5 g/mL and hVISA detected by PAP-AUC  Switch to daptomycin 10 mg/kg/day, linezolid 600 mg q12h, or ceftaroline 600 mg q8h.

Candida auris identification and AST challenges (CRITICAL): C. auris is a CDC urgent threat and WHO critical priority pathogen due to multidrug resistance, environmental persistence, and outbreak potential. Misidentification: Conventional methods (API, Vitek 2) misidentify C. auris as C. haemulonii or C. duobushaemulonii. MALDI-TOF or molecular methods (PCR, sequencing) are required for accurate identification. Multidrug resistance: 90% resistant to fluconazole, 30-40% resistant to amphotericin B, 5-10% resistant to echinocandins (FKS mutations). Infection control implications: Environmental persistence (survives on surfaces for weeks), transmission in healthcare settings (outbreaks in ICUs, LTACHs), contact precautions required, dedicated equipment, environmental disinfection with sporicidal agents (e.g., bleach, hydrogen peroxide vapor). Stewardship implication: Early identification and appropriate antifungal selection (echinocandin first-line; avoid fluconazole).

Fastidious organisms and special testing requirements (HIGH PRIORITY): H. influenzae: Beta-lactamase testing (nitrocefin disk) guides ampicillin use; beta-lactamase-positive strains (30-40% in US) are resistant to ampicillin. Beta-lactamase-negative ampicillin-resistant (BLNAR) strains (5-10%) require MIC testing. M. catarrhalis: >95% produce beta-lactamase; amoxicillin-clavulanate or macrolides preferred. HACEK organisms (Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella): Endocarditis pathogens; require extended incubation (5-7 days), chocolate agar, CO atmosphere. Nutritionally variant streptococci (Abiotrophia, Granulicatella): Endocarditis pathogens; require pyridoxal supplementation for growth. N. meningitidis: Penicillin MIC testing for invasive isolates; ceftriaxone preferred for meningitis. Stewardship implication: Recognize special testing requirements; avoid reporting errors that lead to inappropriate therapy.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae resistance mechanisms (HIGH PRIORITY): Mosaic penA gene: Cephalosporin resistance (MIC creep); strains with mosaic penA have ceftriaxone MIC 0.125 g/mL. 23S rRNA mutations: Azithromycin high-level resistance (MIC 256 g/mL); dual therapy (ceftriaxone + azithromycin) no longer recommended by CDC (2020). Public health implications: CDC Gonococcal Isolate Surveillance Project (GISP) tracks resistance trends; report elevated MICs (ceftriaxone 0.125 g/mL) to public health. Stewardship implication: All N. gonorrhoeae isolates should undergo AST; report elevated MICs to public health; perform test-of-cure culture for concerning MICs.

Stenotrophomonas maltophilia AST considerations: S. maltophilia is intrinsically resistant to most beta-lactams (including carbapenems), aminoglycosides, and many other antibiotics due to efflux pumps and beta-lactamases. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is first-line therapy (S 2 g/mL). Alternative agents: Levofloxacin (S 2 g/mL), minocycline (S 4 g/mL), tigecycline (no CLSI breakpoint), ceftazidime (variable susceptibility, 50-70%). Stewardship implication: Avoid empiric carbapenem use for S. maltophilia (intrinsically resistant); use TMP-SMX or fluoroquinolone. Clinical significance: S. maltophilia is often a colonizer in respiratory specimens; treat only if clinical evidence of infection (fever, leukocytosis, infiltrate on imaging).

Acinetobacter baumannii multidrug resistance: A. baumannii is a WHO critical priority pathogen due to carbapenem resistance and limited treatment options. Carbapenem resistance mechanisms: OXA-type carbapenemases (blaOXA-23, blaOXA-24, blaOXA-58), metallo-beta-lactamases (NDM, VIM, IMP), efflux pumps, porin loss. Colistin as last resort: Nephrotoxicity risk (30-60%), heteroresistance concerns, suboptimal lung penetration. Newer agents: Cefiderocol (siderophore cephalosporin, S 4 g/mL), sulbactam (intrinsic activity against Acinetobacter, 1-2 g q6h). Stewardship implication: Combination therapy often recommended for carbapenem-resistant A. baumannii (CRAB); infectious diseases consultation advised. Regimens: Colistin + meropenem, colistin + tigecycline, cefiderocol monotherapy or combination.

Anaerobic bacteria susceptibility testing: Anaerobic AST is costly, slow (5-7 days), and has limited clinical utility. When to perform: Bacteremia, brain abscess, endocarditis, osteomyelitis, therapeutic failures, surveillance (NOT routine for polymicrobial infections). Bacteroides fragilis group: Metronidazole resistance rare (<1%) but emerging; carbapenem resistance (cfiA gene) increasing (5-10%). Clostridioides difficile: AST not routinely performed (metronidazole and vancomycin remain effective); fidaxomicin and bezlotoxumab not affected by AST. Stewardship implication: Avoid routine anaerobic AST (costly, slow, limited clinical utility); reserve for specific indications.

AST pitfalls and troubleshooting: Disk diffusion vs. MIC discrepancies: Confirm with MIC testing for critical isolates (e.g., MRSA bacteremia, meningitis). Inoculum effect: ESBL-producing organisms may appear susceptible with low inoculum; use standard inoculum (0.5 McFarland). Media composition: Cation concentration affects aminoglycoside and colistin testing; thymidine in media affects sulfonamide/trimethoprim testing. Incubation time and temperature: Extended incubation for fastidious organisms (HACEK 5-7 days); strict temperature control (35C  2C). Quality control failures: Investigate root cause (media, inoculum, incubation, reagents); corrective actions required before reporting patient results.

Beta-lactam allergy assessment and cross-reactivity (CRITICAL FOR STEWARDSHIP): Penicillin allergy is over-reported: 10% of patients report penicillin allergy, but <1% have true IgE-mediated allergy. Most 'allergies' are non-IgE-mediated reactions (rash, GI upset) or childhood reactions that have resolved. Penicillin skin testing: Negative predictive value >95%; allows safe use of penicillins and cephalosporins. Cross-reactivity rates: Penicillin to cephalosporin <2% (previously thought to be 10%); penicillin to carbapenem <1%; penicillin to aztreonam <1% (safe in penicillin allergy); cephalosporin to carbapenem <1%. Side chain cross-reactivity: Amoxicillin and cefadroxil share R1 side chain (higher cross-reactivity); ceftriaxone and cefotaxime share side chain.

Stewardship implications of beta-lactam allergy: Penicillin allergy labels drive unnecessary broad-spectrum antibiotic use (vancomycin for MSSA instead of cefazolin, fluoroquinolones for UTI instead of amoxicillin, carbapenems for ESBL instead of piperacillin-tazobactam). Penicillin allergy delabeling programs reduce broad-spectrum use by 20-30%, improve patient outcomes, and reduce costs. Graded challenge or test dose for low-risk patients (remote history, non-severe reaction). Use of cephalosporins (especially 3rd/4th generation) is safe in most penicillin-allergic patients. Clinical scenario: 55-year-old man with 'penicillin allergy' (rash 20 years ago) with MSSA bacteremia. Current therapy: Vancomycin 15 mg/kg q12h. Stewardship action: Consider penicillin skin testing or direct cefazolin use (preferred over vancomycin for MSSA). If skin testing negative or cefazolin tolerated, update allergy list and use cefazolin 2 g q8h.

Stewardship role in AST interpretation: Reviewing discrepant results with microbiology laboratory (e.g., automated system reports ceftriaxone susceptible for ESBL-producing E. coli, but ESBL confirmation test is positive  report as resistant). Educating prescribers on resistance mechanisms and AST limitations (e.g., vancomycin MIC 1.5-2 g/mL for MRSA bacteremia is associated with treatment failure despite 'susceptible' category). Updating empiric therapy guidelines based on local resistance patterns and antibiogram data (e.g., if ESBL rate >20% in ICU, use carbapenem for empiric sepsis therapy). Advocating for appropriate testing (e.g., vancomycin MIC for MRSA bacteremia, beta-lactamase testing for H. influenzae). Implementing penicillin allergy delabeling programs to reduce unnecessary broad-spectrum antibiotic use.
keyPoints: ESBL detection: Cephalosporin resistance, clavulanate inhibition  avoid cephalosporins even if 'susceptible' (use carbapenem or piperacillin-tazobactam)
AmpC beta-lactamase: Inducible in ESCPM group (Enterobacter, Citrobacter, Serratia)  avoid ceftriaxone/ceftazidime (risk of induction and treatment failure)
Carbapenemase detection: KPC, NDM, OXA-48, VIM, IMP  infection control alerts, public health reporting, ceftazidime-avibactam or cefiderocol
Heteroresistance: hVISA (vancomycin), colistin  not detected by routine AST  associated with treatment failure
C. auris: MALDI-TOF required (misidentified by conventional methods)  90% fluconazole-resistant, 30-40% amphotericin B-resistant  echinocandin first-line
Fastidious organisms: H. influenzae (beta-lactamase testing), HACEK (extended incubation 5-7 days), nutritionally variant streptococci (pyridoxal)
N. gonorrhoeae: Ceftriaxone MIC 0.125 g/mL concerning (MIC creep)  report to public health, test-of-cure
S. maltophilia: Intrinsically carbapenem-resistant  TMP-SMX first-line; A. baumannii: Carbapenem-resistant  colistin, cefiderocol, or combination therapy
Beta-lactam allergy: 10% report, <1% true allergy  penicillin to cephalosporin cross-reactivity <2%  delabeling programs reduce broad-spectrum use by 20-30%

pages.name: Intrinsic Resistance and AST Interpretation
content: Intrinsic resistance is inherent, naturally occurring resistance present in all strains of a bacterial species due to structural or functional characteristics. Unlike acquired resistance (which is gained through genetic mutations or horizontal gene transfer), intrinsic resistance is predictable and consistent across all strains of a species. Understanding intrinsic resistance is critical for antimicrobial stewardship teams to prevent inappropriate prescribing, interpret AST reports correctly, and construct accurate antibiograms.

Definition and Distinction: Intrinsic resistance is resistance that is naturally present in all members of a bacterial species due to inherent structural or functional characteristics (e.g., lack of target, impermeability, efflux pumps, chromosomal enzymes). Acquired resistance is resistance gained through genetic mutations or horizontal gene transfer (e.g., ESBL, carbapenemase, mecA gene). The key distinction is that intrinsic resistance is predictable and consistent across all strains, while acquired resistance is variable and unpredictable.

Mechanisms of Intrinsic Resistance: (1) Lack of target - organism lacks the antimicrobial target (e.g., Mycoplasma lacks cell wall  intrinsically resistant to all beta-lactams); (2) Impermeability - outer membrane prevents drug entry (e.g., Gram-negative bacteria intrinsically resistant to vancomycin due to large molecular size); (3) Efflux pumps - constitutive efflux pumps remove drug before it reaches target (e.g., P. aeruginosa MexAB-OprM efflux pump); (4) Enzymatic inactivation - chromosomally encoded enzymes inactivate drug (e.g., S. maltophilia L1/L2 metallo-beta-lactamases hydrolyze carbapenems); (5) Target modification - inherent target structure prevents drug binding (e.g., Enterococcus low-affinity PBPs  intrinsic resistance to cephalosporins).

Clinical Significance for Stewardship: (1) AST reporting - laboratories should NOT report intrinsically resistant organism-antimicrobial combinations per CLSI M100 Table 1A; (2) Antibiogram construction - intrinsically resistant combinations must be excluded from antibiogram calculations to avoid misleading susceptibility rates; (3) Empiric therapy selection - intrinsic resistance patterns guide appropriate empiric therapy selection and prevent futile therapy; (4) Prescriber education - common prescribing errors involve intrinsically resistant combinations (e.g., cephalosporins for Enterococcus, TMP-SMX for P. aeruginosa); (5) Quality assurance - intrinsic resistance patterns serve as internal quality control for AST accuracy.

Gram-Positive Intrinsic Resistance - Enterococcus spp.: Enterococcus species are intrinsically resistant to cephalosporins (all generations) due to low-affinity PBPs  never use cephalosporins for Enterococcus infections, even if AST reports 'susceptible' (reporting error). Enterococcus is intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides (low-level) due to impermeability  aminoglycosides require synergy with cell wall-active agent (ampicillin or vancomycin) for bactericidal activity in endocarditis. Enterococcus faecium is intrinsically resistant to ampicillin (most strains) due to PBP5 alteration  use vancomycin or linezolid for E. faecium. Enterococcus is intrinsically resistant to clindamycin due to lack of target  never use clindamycin for Enterococcus.

Gram-Positive Intrinsic Resistance - Staphylococcus saprophyticus: S. saprophyticus is intrinsically resistant to novobiocin due to efflux  this is a diagnostic marker used to differentiate S. saprophyticus (novobiocin-resistant coagulase-negative Staphylococcus) from other coagulase-negative staphylococci. S. saprophyticus is a common cause of uncomplicated urinary tract infections in young women.

Gram-Negative Intrinsic Resistance - Pseudomonas aeruginosa: P. aeruginosa is intrinsically resistant to ampicillin, amoxicillin, amoxicillin-clavulanate, 1st-generation cephalosporins (cefazolin), and 2nd-generation cephalosporins (cefuroxime, cefoxitin) due to impermeability (low outer membrane permeability) and constitutive efflux pumps (MexAB-OprM, MexXY-OprM). P. aeruginosa is also intrinsically resistant to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole due to efflux. For P. aeruginosa infections, use antipseudomonal agents only: ceftazidime, cefepime, piperacillin-tazobactam, carbapenems (meropenem, imipenem, doripenem), fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin), or aminoglycosides (tobramycin, amikacin).

Gram-Negative Intrinsic Resistance - Stenotrophomonas maltophilia: S. maltophilia is intrinsically resistant to all carbapenems (meropenem, imipenem, doripenem, ertapenem) due to chromosomally encoded L1 and L2 metallo-beta-lactamases that hydrolyze carbapenems. S. maltophilia is also intrinsically resistant to most beta-lactams. First-line therapy for S. maltophilia is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX); alternatives include levofloxacin, minocycline, or ceftazidime (variable susceptibility). Never use carbapenems for S. maltophilia, even if AST reports 'susceptible' (reporting error).

Gram-Negative Intrinsic Resistance - Burkholderia cepacia: B. cepacia is intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides and colistin due to impermeability. B. cepacia is a significant pathogen in cystic fibrosis patients and is associated with 'cepacia syndrome' (rapid clinical deterioration). First-line therapy for B. cepacia is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or ceftazidime; meropenem may be effective for some strains. Avoid aminoglycosides and colistin for B. cepacia infections.

Gram-Negative Intrinsic Resistance - Serratia, Morganella, Proteus, Providencia: Serratia marcescens is intrinsically resistant to colistin and polymyxin B due to lipopolysaccharide (LPS) modification  avoid colistin for Serratia infections. Morganella morganii and Providencia spp. are intrinsically resistant to colistin and polymyxin B due to LPS modification. Proteus spp. (P. mirabilis, P. vulgaris) are intrinsically resistant to tigecycline due to efflux  never use tigecycline for Proteus infections. These organisms are part of the SPICE group (Serratia, Pseudomonas, indole-positive Proteus, Citrobacter, Enterobacter) with inducible AmpC beta-lactamases.

Gram-Negative Intrinsic Resistance - Acinetobacter baumannii: A. baumannii is intrinsically resistant to ertapenem due to impermeability (ertapenem has poor activity against Acinetobacter)  use meropenem or imipenem instead (NOT ertapenem). Sulbactam has intrinsic activity against A. baumannii due to PBP binding  ampicillin-sulbactam 9 g q8h (sulbactam 3 g component) may be effective for carbapenem-resistant A. baumannii. A. baumannii is a critical priority pathogen per WHO 2024 list due to high rates of carbapenem resistance.

Anaerobic Intrinsic Resistance: All anaerobic bacteria (Bacteroides fragilis, Clostridium spp., Peptostreptococcus spp., Fusobacterium spp.) are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides because aminoglycosides require oxygen for active uptake into bacterial cells (oxygen-dependent transport)  never use aminoglycosides for anaerobic infections. Clostridioides difficile is intrinsically resistant to most cephalosporins due to efflux  cephalosporins are a major risk factor for C. difficile infection (CDI) due to disruption of gut microbiota.

Fungal Intrinsic Resistance - Candida krusei: C. krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole due to altered target (ERG11 gene mutation)  use echinocandin (caspofungin, micafungin, anidulafungin) or amphotericin B first-line for C. krusei infections. C. krusei accounts for 2-5% of candidemia cases and is associated with prior fluconazole exposure. Never use fluconazole for C. krusei, even if AST reports 'susceptible' (reporting error).

Fungal Intrinsic Resistance - Candida glabrata: C. glabrata is intrinsically susceptible-dose dependent (SDD) to fluconazole due to efflux pumps (CDR1, CDR2)  high-dose fluconazole (800 mg daily) may be effective, but echinocandins are preferred first-line therapy. C. glabrata accounts for 15-20% of candidemia cases and is the second most common Candida species after C. albicans. C. glabrata is also developing echinocandin resistance (FKS mutations) in 5-10% of cases.

Fungal Intrinsic Resistance - Aspergillus and Mucorales: Aspergillus spp. are intrinsically resistant to fluconazole due to lack of target  use voriconazole or isavuconazole first-line for invasive aspergillosis. Mucorales (Rhizopus, Mucor, Rhizomucor) are intrinsically resistant to voriconazole and posaconazole due to lack of target  use amphotericin B first-line for mucormycosis. Mucormycosis is associated with diabetic ketoacidosis, hematologic malignancies, and solid organ transplantation.

Atypical Organisms Intrinsic Resistance: Mycoplasma pneumoniae and Chlamydia spp. (C. pneumoniae, C. trachomatis) are intrinsically resistant to all beta-lactams because they lack a cell wall (no peptidoglycan)  use macrolides (azithromycin, clarithromycin), fluoroquinolones (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin), or tetracyclines (doxycycline) for atypical pneumonia. Legionella pneumophila is intrinsically resistant to most beta-lactams due to intracellular location  use macrolides or fluoroquinolones for Legionnaires' disease.

CLSI Guidance on Intrinsic Resistance Reporting: CLSI M100 35th Edition (2025) Table 1A provides a comprehensive list of intrinsic resistance patterns that should NOT be reported by clinical microbiology laboratories. If an organism appears 'susceptible' to an intrinsically resistant antimicrobial, this indicates: (1) Organism misidentification (e.g., Enterococcus misidentified as Streptococcus); (2) AST methodology error (e.g., wrong panel, wrong incubation conditions); (3) Reporting error (e.g., manual transcription error). Stewardship teams should review AST reports for inappropriate reporting of intrinsically resistant combinations and alert the laboratory to investigate.

Antibiogram Construction and Intrinsic Resistance: When constructing institutional antibiograms per CLSI M39 guidelines, intrinsically resistant organism-antimicrobial combinations must be excluded from susceptibility calculations. For example, when calculating ceftriaxone susceptibility for Gram-negative organisms, exclude Enterococcus, Stenotrophomonas, Burkholderia, and other intrinsically resistant organisms. Failure to exclude intrinsically resistant combinations will artificially inflate susceptibility rates and mislead prescribers.

Common Prescribing Errors Involving Intrinsic Resistance: (1) Prescribing cephalosporins for Enterococcus (e.g., ceftriaxone for E. faecalis UTI)  stewardship intervention: switch to ampicillin or nitrofurantoin; (2) Prescribing TMP-SMX for P. aeruginosa (e.g., TMP-SMX for P. aeruginosa UTI)  stewardship intervention: switch to ciprofloxacin or ceftazidime; (3) Prescribing carbapenems for S. maltophilia (e.g., meropenem for S. maltophilia pneumonia)  stewardship intervention: switch to TMP-SMX; (4) Prescribing fluconazole for C. krusei (e.g., fluconazole for C. krusei candidemia)  stewardship intervention: switch to echinocandin; (5) Prescribing beta-lactams for atypical pneumonia (e.g., ceftriaxone monotherapy for Mycoplasma pneumonia)  stewardship intervention: add macrolide or switch to fluoroquinolone.

Quality Assurance and Intrinsic Resistance: Intrinsic resistance patterns serve as internal quality control for AST accuracy. If an organism appears 'susceptible' to an intrinsically resistant antimicrobial, investigate: (1) Organism identification - confirm species identification using MALDI-TOF or 16S rRNA sequencing; (2) AST methodology - verify correct panel, media, incubation conditions, and inoculum density; (3) Quality control strains - review QC data for the same antimicrobial-organism combination; (4) Reporting process - check for manual transcription errors or software errors. Document the investigation and corrective action in the laboratory quality management system.

Stewardship Interventions for Intrinsic Resistance Errors: When stewardship teams identify prescribing of intrinsically resistant agents: (1) Immediate intervention - contact prescriber to modify order (phone call or electronic alert); (2) Education - explain intrinsic resistance pattern and appropriate alternatives; (3) Documentation - document intervention in medical record and stewardship database; (4) Follow-up - verify order modification and clinical response; (5) Aggregate data - track frequency of intrinsic resistance errors by prescriber, service, and organism to identify educational opportunities. Common interventions include switching cephalosporins to ampicillin for Enterococcus, switching TMP-SMX to ciprofloxacin for P. aeruginosa, and switching carbapenems to TMP-SMX for S. maltophilia.
keyPoints: Intrinsic resistance is inherent and predictable: All strains of a species share the same intrinsic resistance pattern (unlike acquired resistance)
Enterococcus intrinsic resistance: Resistant to cephalosporins (all), aminoglycosides (low-level), clindamycin  use ampicillin (E. faecalis) or vancomycin/linezolid (E. faecium)

P. aeruginosa intrinsic resistance: Resistant to ampicillin, 1st/2nd-gen cephalosporins, TMP-SMX  use antipseudomonal agents only (ceftazidime, cefepime, piperacillin-tazobactam, carbapenems, fluoroquinolones)
S. maltophilia intrinsic carbapenem resistance: Resistant to all carbapenems due to L1/L2 metallo-beta-lactamases  use TMP-SMX first-line
Anaerobes intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides: Aminoglycosides require oxygen for uptake  never use for anaerobic infections
C. krusei intrinsically resistant to fluconazole: Use echinocandin or amphotericin B first-line
Atypical organisms intrinsically resistant to beta-lactams: Mycoplasma, Chlamydia, Legionella lack cell wall  use macrolides, fluoroquinolones, or tetracyclines
AST reporting rule: Laboratories should NOT report intrinsically resistant organism-antimicrobial combinations per CLSI M100 Table 1A
Stewardship red flag: Prescribing intrinsically resistant agents is a stewardship intervention opportunity (education, order modification)
Antibiogram exclusion: Intrinsically resistant combinations must be excluded from antibiogram calculations to avoid misleading susceptibility rates
